Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: High Dimensional Statistics -- Adaptive Networks, Structure and Robustness

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Data-driven adaptation has emerged as a powerful paradigm for algorithm design in engineered, social, and biological large-scale complex systems. Many phenomena in complex dynamical networks are naturally high dimensional: a model?s dimensionality may equal or exceed the number of data points one can collect or experiments one can perform. This novel regime poses severe algorithmic, computational and analytical challenges.

Intellectual Merit: Low-dimensional structure ? often hidden but prevalent in many complex systems ? offers a way forward. We propose an essentially complete rethinking of Robust Optimization: imagining fictitious parameter uncertainty we design a new algorithmic framework for finding and exploiting structure. This greatly broadens the scope of problems where structure can be exploited, unifying results that previously seemed disconnected, and opening the door for the design of new efficient and provably effective
algorithms. Then, marrying essential ideas of robust optimization with tools from high-dimensional statistics, we explore robustness to potentially severe data corruption in high-dimensions ? a problem that classical robust statistics has largely been unable to address.

Broader Impacts: Curriculum initiatives include a vertical and horizontal integration of data-driven techniques in new curriculum. The work will influence and be motivated by strong connections to industry partners. High-dimensional data will become increasingly pervasive (the length of genomes sequenced increases; the number of patients carrying a genetic disease does not). Many questions critical to society, science and our future depend fundamentally on successful analysis and efficient, robust algorithms for the high dimensional regime; the impact to real applications promises to be immense.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Data-driven adaptation has emerged as a powerful paradigm for algorithm design in a broad array of engineered, social, and biological large-scale complex systems. A novel regime of computational, analytical, and algorithmic challenges stems from the fact that accurate models of many phenomena in complex dynamical networks are naturally very high dimensional. A single data point might be a protein's structure and function, a trace of consumer financial data, pairwise interactions in a social network or a snapshot of data collected by an autonomous vehicle's high resolution, multi-modal sensors. The vast promise of exploiting these data to learn about disease, the environment, or the economy hinges on our ability to find hidden structure in these high dimensional data, while making sure we are not finding patterns where in fact there are none, or missing patterns because of noise or corruption in the data. 

This proposal funded Prof. Constantine Caramanis and Ph.D. students to develop novel methods in optimization and machine learning, to attack precisely this set of problems. The key insight developed is that robustness and structure display an important duality: algorithms that successfully hedge against noise or irregularities in the data also identify important structure in the data; and conversely, an algorithm that succeeds in finding important structural patterns in the data, is also robust.

Specifically, this lead to the development  of algorithms that are resilient to large amounts of missing data. This is important, since faulty sensors, occluded measurements, incomplete surveys, etc., are a hallmark of real-world data in important applications. Prof. Caramanis and his group also designed algorithms that were provably resilient to manipulated data. That is, the group developed algorithms that could find correct (true) patterns in data, even when some part of the data set had been manipulated, perhaps by an adversary seeking to fool the learning algorithm. These algorithmic and theoretical advances have direct applicationt to a broad array of important areas. To illustrate this breadth, these include, for instance, epidemiology and the discovery of new human and computer viruses, and also recommendation engines and personalization.

The Ph.D. students supported by this award are continuing their research careers, some as researchers and educators in universities, and some as researchers in technology companies.
